verses.text: Then Pilate took Jesus and had Him flogged.
verses.comment: Pilate, the Roman governor, orders Jesus to be scourged. This brutal punishment fulfills the suffering foretold by Isaiah (Isa. 53:5), linking the physical suffering of Jesus with His role as the suffering Servant.

verses.text: The soldiers twisted a crown of thorns and put it on His head, and clothed Him in a purple robe.
verses.comment: The crown of thorns and purple robe are acts of mockery, but they ironically symbolize Jesus' kingship—a theme deeply important to understanding both His divinity and His mission as King and Messiah (Isa. 9:6-7; Luke 1:32-33).

verses.text: They kept coming up to Him, saying, 'Hail, King of the Jews!' and slapping Him in the face.
verses.comment: Their mockery ironically proclaims a truth: Jesus is the true King. This fulfillment of prophecy highlights how God’s sovereignty works even through human injustice (Ps. 2:6).

verses.text: Pilate went out again and said to them, 'Look, I am bringing Him out to you so that you may know that I find no guilt in Him.'
verses.comment: Pilate’s repeated declaration of Jesus’ innocence is significant. It demonstrates that Jesus is the blameless lamb, prepared for sacrifice (Exod. 12:5; Isa. 53:9).

verses.text: Then Jesus came out, wearing the crown of thorns and the purple robe. Pilate said to them, 'Here is the man!'
verses.comment: 'Here is the man!' echoes Old Testament Messianic language (cf. Zechariah 6:12, 'the man whose name is the Branch') and highlights both His humanity and His sacrificial role.

verses.text: When the chief priests and the officers saw Him, they cried out, 'Crucify Him! Crucify Him!' Pilate said to them, 'Take Him yourselves and crucify Him, for I find no guilt in Him.'
verses.comment: Pilate’s reluctance underscores Jesus’ innocence—again referencing the spotless nature of the sacrificial victim, as required in Old Testament law. The crowds’ demand fulfills prophecy about rejection of the Messiah (Isa. 53:3).

verses.text: The Jews answered him, 'We have a law, and according to that law He ought to die, because He claimed to be the Son of God.'
verses.comment: Jesus’ claim to be the Son of God is a declaration of divinity within the context of Jewish law, which interprets such a claim as blasphemy (see Leviticus 24:16). This further reveals His divine identity and purpose.

verses.text: When Pilate heard this statement, he was even more afraid.
verses.comment: Pilate’s fear reflects a recognition of the gravity of Jesus’ claim and perhaps an instinctive understanding that something extraordinary is unfolding.

verses.text: He went back into the headquarters and said to Jesus, 'Where are You from?' But Jesus did not give him an answer.
verses.comment: Jesus’ silence fulfills Isaiah 53:7—'He was oppressed and afflicted, yet He did not open His mouth.' Pilate’s question points to Jesus’ unique origin.

verses.text: So Pilate said to Him, 'You do not speak to me? Do You not know that I have power to release You, and power to crucify You?'
verses.comment: Pilate asserts his worldly authority, but the scene hints at a deeper spiritual authority belonging to Jesus.

verses.text: Jesus answered him, 'You would have no power over Me unless it had been given to you from above. For this reason, the one who handed Me over to you has the greater sin.'
verses.comment: Here Jesus reveals that all earthly authority comes from God. He also highlights the responsibility and culpability of those who betray Him—foreshadowing the seriousness of betrayal and leadership in the Church.

verses.text: From then on, Pilate sought to release Him, but the Jews kept shouting, 'If you release this man, you are no friend of Caesar. Everyone who claims to be a king opposes Caesar.'
verses.comment: Political tension and fear of losing favour with Rome push Pilate to act against his conscience— a subtle warning about compromising truth for power.

verses.text: When Pilate heard these words, he brought Jesus out and sat down on the judgment seat at a place called The Stone Pavement, in Hebrew, Gabbatha.
verses.comment: The Stone Pavement (Gabbatha) is the official place of judgment, showing that Jesus was publicly condemned in view of all. This setting marks a pivotal moment in salvation history.

verses.text: Now it was the day of preparation for the Passover. It was about noon. Pilate said to the Jews, 'Here is your King!'
verses.comment: Jesus is condemned at the very hour the Passover lambs were being prepared—a sign that He is the true Paschal Lamb. Pilate’s words recognize a kingship overlooked by many.

verses.text: They cried out, 'Away with Him! Away with Him! Crucify Him!' Pilate said to them, 'Shall I crucify your King?' The chief priests answered, 'We have no king but Caesar.'
verses.comment: The leaders’ rejection of Jesus as King fulfills prophecies about Israel’s rejection of God’s chosen one. Their allegiance to Caesar over God is a tragic reversal of Israel’s calling.

verses.text: So then he handed Him over to them to be crucified. They took Jesus away.
verses.comment: Pilate’s surrender to the crowd marks the final earthly condemnation. Jesus is led away, showing His submission and fulfillment of prophecy (Isa. 53:7).

verses.text: Carrying His own cross, He went out to the place called The Skull, which in Hebrew is called Golgotha.
verses.comment: Jesus carries His own cross, fulfilling His words about self-giving (cf. Matt. 16:24). Golgotha, the place of execution, ties to the Old Testament imagery of the sacrificial altar.

verses.text: There they crucified Him, and with Him two others, one on either side, and Jesus in the middle.
verses.comment: Jesus is numbered with sinners in His crucifixion, fulfilling Isaiah 53:12. The two criminals beside Him emphasize His solidarity with humanity.

verses.text: Pilate wrote a title and put it on the cross. It said, 'Jesus of Nazareth, the King of the Jews.'
verses.comment: The inscription proclaims Jesus’ kingship to all. Even in His death, His true identity is displayed publicly.

verses.text: Many of the Jews read this sign, because the place where Jesus was crucified was near the city, and it was written in Hebrew, Latin, and Greek.
verses.comment: The trilingual inscription symbolizes the universality of Jesus’ kingship—He is king for all nations and peoples.

verses.text: So the chief priests of the Jews said to Pilate, 'Do not write,
Pilate answered, 'What I have written, I have written.'
verses.comment: Pilate's final statement reinforces the truth about Jesus' identity. God uses even secular rulers to proclaim the reality of who Jesus is.

verses.text: When the soldiers had crucified Jesus, they took His clothes and divided them into four parts, one part for each soldier, and also His tunic. Now the tunic was seamless, woven in one piece from top to bottom.
verses.comment: The division of Jesus' garments fulfills the prophecy in Psalm 22:18. The seamless tunic hints at unity and wholeness, subtly symbolizing the unbroken garment of the one, true Church.

verses.text: So they said to one another, 'Let us not tear it, but cast lots for it to see whose it will be.' This happened so that the Scripture might be fulfilled: 'They divided My clothes among them, and for My clothing they cast lots.' So the soldiers did these things.
verses.comment: The careful fulfillment of this prophecy highlights God's providence and the divine orchestration in the hour of Christ's suffering.

verses.text: Standing near Jesus' cross were His mother, His mother's sister, Mary wife of Clopas, and Mary Magdalene.
verses.comment: The presence of Jesus' mother at the cross is deeply meaningful. It connects her ongoing relationship with Christ and her unique role in salvation history (Gen. 3:15; Luke 2:35).

verses.text: When Jesus saw His mother and the disciple whom He loved standing nearby, He said to His mother, 'Woman, behold your son!'
verses.comment: Jesus entrusts His mother to John, the beloved disciple. This act has profound spiritual meaning—it points to the creation of a new family in Christ, with the disciple representing all believers.

verses.text: Then He said to the disciple, 'Behold, your mother!' And from that hour the disciple took her into his own home.
verses.comment: By giving His mother to John, Jesus establishes a spiritual motherhood for the community of believers. This passage underlines the special, continuing role of Mary in the life of the Church.

verses.text: After this, knowing that everything was now finished, and to fulfill the Scripture, Jesus said, 'I am thirsty.'
verses.comment: Jesus’ statement fulfills prophecy (Psalm 22:15; 69:21). It shows His true humanity and the fulfillment of the suffering predicted for the Messiah.

verses.text: A jar full of sour wine was there. So they soaked a sponge in the sour wine, put it on a hyssop branch, and raised it to His mouth.
verses.comment: The hyssop branch is significant—it was used in the Passover ritual (Exodus 12:22), reinforcing Jesus as the true Passover Lamb.

verses.text: When Jesus had taken the wine, He said, 'It is finished.' Then, bowing His head, He gave up His spirit.
verses.comment: 'It is finished' marks the completion of Jesus' mission—He fulfills every Messianic prophecy regarding His suffering. The voluntary giving up of His spirit suggests divine authority over life and death.

verses.text: Since it was the day of Preparation, and so that the bodies would not remain on the cross during the Sabbath—for that Sabbath was a high day—the Jews asked Pilate to have their legs broken and the bodies taken away.
verses.comment: Jewish law required burial before the Sabbath, highlighting the intersection of tradition and the unfolding of God’s plan.

verses.text: So the soldiers came and broke the legs of the first, and of the other who had been crucified with Him.
verses.comment: Breaking the legs hastened death, ensuring the crucified would not remain alive into the Sabbath.

verses.text: But when they came to Jesus and saw that He was already dead, they did not break His legs.
verses.comment: This fulfills scripture—none of the bones of the Passover lamb were to be broken, showing Jesus’ complete fulfillment of the sacrificial laws.

verses.text: But one of the soldiers pierced His side with a spear, and immediately blood and water flowed out.
verses.comment: The blood and water from Jesus’ side have profound sacramental significance, pointing to both baptism and the Eucharist as means of grace flowing from Christ’s sacrifice.

verses.text: He who saw this has testified, and his testimony is true; he knows that he speaks the truth, so that you also may believe.
verses.comment: John emphasizes the eyewitness nature of his account, affirming the historical reality of Christ’s death and the importance of believing in Him.

verses.text: For these things happened so that the Scripture would be fulfilled: 'Not one of His bones will be broken.'
verses.comment: A direct fulfillment of Old Testament prophecies about the Messiah, reinforcing Jesus as the true Passover Lamb.

verses.text: And again, another Scripture says, 'They will look at Him whom they pierced.'
verses.comment: The piercing of Jesus fulfills Zechariah 12:10, signifying recognition and repentance—the people will mourn for the one they have pierced.

verses.text: After these things, Joseph of Arimathea, who was a disciple of Jesus but secretly because he feared the Jews, asked Pilate that he might take away the body of Jesus. Pilate gave permission, so he came and took His body away.
verses.comment: Joseph of Arimathea’s care for Jesus’ body shows reverence, love, and fulfillment of prophecy about the burial of the Messiah (Isa. 53:9).

verses.text: Nicodemus, who had come to Jesus previously at night, also came, bringing a mixture of myrrh and aloes, about seventy-five pounds in weight.
verses.comment: Nicodemus’ costly gift recalls anointing and burial customs often reserved for royalty, further underlining Jesus’ kingship and the reverence shown by His followers.

verses.text: So they took Jesus’ body and wrapped it in linen cloths with the spices, according to the Jewish burial custom.
verses.comment: Jesus receives a reverent burial, paralleling kingly, priestly, and sacrificial motifs from Old Testament tradition.

verses.text: In the place where He was crucified there was a garden, and in the garden a new tomb in which no one had yet been laid.
verses.comment: The new tomb underscores the purity of Jesus’ sacrifice and the beginning of new life and creation—even as Adam’s fall happened in a garden, Christ’s victory is here inaugurated.

verses.text: Because it was the Jewish day of Preparation and the tomb was nearby, they laid Jesus there.
verses.comment: Jesus is hastily buried because of the Sabbath. This careful concern for the body echoes the reverence for sacraments and sacred things in God’s people throughout Scripture.
